title: Fixing childcare rip off of working mums could boost economy by $700m
text:
"The financial cliffs just cannot make sense, so this is an urgent and critical issue for the government to address," Ms Kitchen said.

“By alleviating the cost of childcare, targeted spending can remove a major

barrier facing primary carers seeking to return to work.

Chief Executive Women president Sue Morphett says tackling the childcare distortion would help even the playing fields for couples. Fairfax Media

"The current system creates some really perverse outcomes where women are paying to work. Earning just one extra dollar can cause a family to lose up to $5000 of subsidy," she said.

For example, a mother earning the full-time equivalent of $100,000 per year whose spouse earns $100,000 per annum would take home just an extra $5000 a year by increasing her work days from three to four.

Worse, the family goes backwards by $4200 a year if she increased her working days from four to five.

Big productivity boost

KPMG proposes capping the work disincentive rate for the secondary earner – usually a woman – at the marginal income tax rate, plus 20 percentage points, creating a progressive system.

Advertisement

"This would benefit households across the income scale, but especially those at modest incomes who can least afford to be prevented from working more hours," Ms Kitchen said.

KPMG's lead tax partner Grant Wardell‐Johnson said its alternative proposal was for the government to provide additional assistance for families with more than one child in long-day care.

The subsidy reimburses a maximum of 85 per cent of the childcare costs for each child. KPMG suggests that for the second (and any additional) child in simultaneous long-day care, the subsidy should be increased to 100 per cent for all households, regardless of their income.

"Given Australia’s weak productivity performance, it is crucial that we make better use of the skills and experience of many parents who have taken time out of the workforce to bring up children," Mr Wardell‐Johnson said.

“Our economic modelling in this report shows the proposals would generate an additional $678 million – using conservative assumptions – at a cost of $368 million in extra CCS spending."

Ms Morphett said increased affordability of childcare would be a key enabler of greater parental equality in our society.

“Reducing financial disincentives for parents seeking to work full-time is paramount," she said.

"If we aspire to have equal workforce participation and leadership progression we must ensure men and women are equally empowered, socially and financially, to share the income-generating and care-giving roles.”
description: A new report finds more than 125,000 working mothers are being penalised for choosing to work more days.
